awd_abstract_narration:
This award in the Chemical Synthesis (SYN) program supports work by Professor Christopher C. Cummins at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to carry out fundamental studies on the chemistry of compounds containing group 15 elements, with emphasis on nitrogen, phosphorus, and arsenic.  Methods for the direct incorporation of atmospheric nitrogen into organic molecules will be sought in order to bypass the ammonia intermediate that is generated in the traditional energy-intensive ammonia synthesis process.  This could remove the requirement for fossil fuel-derived hydrogen in the synthesis of organonitrogen compounds.  Elemental phosphorus is the industrial precursor to specialty chemicals that contain this element, including those required as flame-retardants and lithium battery electrolytes.  The present technique of initial phosphorus chlorination is wasteful, most obviously when chlorine is not present in the synthetic target.  Methods are sought for a more direct incorporation of phosphorus into value-added materials.  Modern technology benefits from advanced semiconducting materials including gallium phosphide and indium arsenide.  Methods will be developed for the controlled and selective incorporation of nitrogen, phosphorus, and arsenic into advanced materials.

Nitrogen and phosphorus are biogenic elements whose global cycles impact life on Earth directly, as they are required in large amounts for the synthesis of both DNA and proteins.  These elements also have indirect impact, as nitrogen fixation for fertilizer manufacture is energy-intensive, and the loss of phosphorus to the oceans in ground water causes blooms of eutrophication.  Efficient processes for incorporation of group 15 elements into essential compounds are required technology for responsible stewardship of our precious elemental resources.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
p { margin-bottom: 0.1in; line-height: 120%; }

Building on our prior discovery of photochemical combination of elemental phosphorus with organic molecules, we partnered with a theory group to gain understanding of the reaction mechanism. We developed new reagents for the transfer of the reactive species diphosphorus to organic acceptors. The organophosphorus compounds so obtained were found to be robust and to represent a valuable new type of building block for synthetic investigations. For example, we found that they self-assemble bimetallic complexes when mixed in a 3:2 ratio with zerovalent nickel, palladium, or platinum. Phosphinidenes are reactive, unsaturated phosphorus-containing intermediates; we developed new precursors to them of a kind that previously were thought not to be stable enough to exist. The new precursors are easy to make and represent an excellent starting point for much new chemistry. The method used might be more general and extensible to other elements, such as germanium. We discovered new reactions for the transformation of elemental phosphorus; in one example, we found that a molecule containing a niobium-phosphorus triple bond reacts with white phosphorus to generate a cyclo-triphosphorus unit that stays bonded to the metal. We also discovered new pathways to assemble molecules containing metal-phosphorus multiple bonds. We showed that it is possible to synthesize carbon-phosphorus multiply bonded species directly from carbon dioxide using niobium chemistry. Having discovered how to synthesize a molecule composed of a single arsenic atom and three phosphorus atoms, we carried out a collaborative study of its structure in the gas phase by microwave spectroscopy. We showed that it is also possible to prepare the molecular arsenic triphosphide when using a neutral source of triphosphorus. We developed new phosphide reagents that might be used to prepare materials having desirable electronic properties such as indium phosphide. In the field of oxidation chemistry, an important class of reaction is one in which a single oxygen atom is transferred from a donor to an acceptor; we carried out illuminating studies of the mechanism of oxygen atom transfer from a set of nitrogen oxides to a vanadium acceptor. In advancing the chemistry of elemental nitrogen we carried out a collaborative study of photochemical cleavage of the very strong N—N bond. We investigated a new scheme for incorporation of elemental nitrogen into organic molecules via cyanate.

These studies formed the basis for the Ph.D. thesis research of two graduate students who have both now graduated and are presently carrying out postdoctoral studies, one at Columbia University and one at Texas A&M University prior to embarking on science careers in USA academia or chemical industry. It was carried out with the participation of MIT undergraduate students who have now gone on to graduate studies in chemistry. Also participating were postdoctoral researchers and visiting students from overseas who came with their own fellowship funding. The research accomplishments laid the groundwork for new research investigations currently taking place in our laboratories and together with collaborators. Our investigations into the chemistry of elemental phosphorus came with some additional support and interest from the phosphorus chemical industry where there is a recognized need for new, greener methods for the synthesis of phosphorus-containing compounds. Together with our published fundamental scientific findings, the education of undergraduate and graduate students, and the advanced training of postdoctoral scientists and visiting scholars, make up the most significant outcomes from the award.
